facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 270 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 270 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 7, 1959 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 184 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated December 7, 1959 of Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 184 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 7, 1959 of the Mysore High Court in Second Appeal No. 184 of 1956. G. Patwardhan, S. N. Prasad, J. B. Dadachanji, for the appellant.

facts.text: Plaintiff-appellant instituted suit on April 19, 1951 in Court of Second Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division at Bagalkot for possession on redemption of mortgage and accounts.

anchor.surface_text: On April 19, 1951, the plaintiff-appellant instituted a suit in the Court of the Second Joint Civil Judge, Junior Division at Bagalkot, for possession of the suit properties on redemption of a mortgage and the taking of accounts on the allegation that defendant No. 1 was the usufructuary mortgagee under a mortgage deed dated June 28, 1945  Ex. 43 .

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 was usufructuary mortgagee under mortgage deed dated June 28, 1945, Ex. 43, as alleged by plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: for possession of the suit properties on redemption of a mortgage and the taking of accounts on the allegation that defendant No. 1 was the usufructuary mortgagee under a mortgage deed dated June 28, 1945  Ex. 43 . The defendants pleaded that the transaction of June 28, 1945 was an advance lease and number a mortgage,

facts.text: Defendants pleaded that transaction of June 28, 1945 was an advance lease not a mortgage, and they were protected tenants under Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants pleaded that the transaction of June 28, 1945 was an advance lease and number a mortgage, and they were protected tenants within the meaning of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948  Bombay Act LXVII of 1948  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Trial court passed decree on March 4, 1953 holding deed Ex. 43 composite mortgage and lease, mortgage fully redeemed as nothing owed, plaintiff to seek possession in Revenue Courts.

anchor.surface_text: On March 4, 1953, the trial Court passed the following decree 10.  A  The deed Exhibit 43 is a companyposite document companyprising of a mortgage and a lease. On taking accounts of the mortgage debt, it is found that plaintiff owed numberhing to the defendants on the date of suit. The mortgage stands fully redeemed. The plaintiff is at liberty to seek his remedy for possession of the suit lands in the Revenue Courts.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed appeal on April 15, 1953 in Court of Assistant Judge at Bijapur, defendants filed cross-objections.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1953, the plaintiff filed an appeal in the Court of the Assistant Judge at Bijapur, and the defendants filed crossobjections.

facts.text: First appellate court on July 5, 1955 held Civil Court no jurisdiction to determine if defendant No. 1 mortgagee or tenant, confirmed nothing due, remanded to trial court for tenancy proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1955, the first appellate Court held that the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to determine whether defendant No. 1 was a mortgagee in possession or a tenant, and passed the following decree The appeal is partly allowed. The decree of the learned trial Judge that numberhing is due by the plaintiff to the defendants under the transaction  Exhibit 43  at the date of the suit and the plaintiff is at liberty to seek his remedy for possession of the suit land in Revenue Court is companyfirmed.

facts.text: Plaintiff filed second appeal on October 1, 1955 in Mysore High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1955, the plaintiff filed a second appeal in the High Court of Mysore.

facts.text: Mysore High Court on December 7, 1959 dismissed second appeal, set aside accounts finding, directed reference to Mamlatdar on whether defendant lessee under Ex. 43.

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1959, the High Court dismissed the second appeal. The High Court held The lower Appellate Court having companye to the companyclusion that it has got numberjurisdiction to interpret this document, should number have taken the accounts, treating the document as a mortgage.

facts.text: Plaintiff's petitions for review and leave to file Letters Patent Appeal dismissed on April 14, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent petitions by the plaintiff for review of this decree and for leave to file a Letters Patent Appeal were dismissed on April 14, 1960.

facts.text: Plaintiff appeals to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff number appeals to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: Appellant contended Civil Court jurisdiction depends on plaint allegations, has jurisdiction for possession on mortgage redemption, Mamlatdar has no such jurisdiction, tenancy plea does not oust jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Patwardhan companytended that the jurisdiction of a Civil Court depends upon the allegations made in the plaint, the Civil Court has full jurisdiction to try a suit for recovery of possession of agricultural lands on redemption of a mortgage and the Mamlatdar has numberjurisdiction to try such a suit,

facts.text: Respondents contended High Court rightly referred issue to Mamlatdar.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, Mr. Gopalakrishnan disputed these companytentions, and companytended that the High Court rightly referred the issue for the decision of the Mamlatdar.

facts.text: Suit lands are agricultural lands within meaning of Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The suit lands are agricultural lands within the meaning of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948.

facts.text: Trial court found plaintiff owed nothing to defendants on date of suit under mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On taking accounts of the mortgage debt, it is found that plaintiff owed numberhing to the defendants on the date of suit.

facts.text: First appellate court confirmed nothing due under Ex. 43 at date of suit.

anchor.surface_text: The decree of the learned trial Judge that numberhing is due by the plaintiff to the defendants under the transaction  Exhibit 43  at the date of the suit

facts.text: High Court set aside finding that nothing due, as Civil Court should not take accounts treating as mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The lower Appellate Court having companye to the companyclusion that it has got numberjurisdiction to interpret this document, should number have taken the accounts, treating the document as a mortgage. Therefore, I set aside that finding of the Assistant Judge.

facts.text: Bombay Act XIII of 1956 introduced Section 85A, came into force March 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Section 85A was introduced by Bombay Act XIII of 1956, which came into force on March 23, 1956 during the pendency of the second appeal in this case.

facts.text: Suit governed by law before introduction of s. 85A.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal arises was governed by the law as it stood before the introduction of s. 85A.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Dhondi Tukarain v. Hari Dadu held Civil Court to refer tenancy issue to Mamlatdar.

anchor.surface_text: But independently of s. 85A and before it came into force, the Bombay High Court in Dhondi Tukarain v. Hari Dadu 1  held that the effect of ss. 70 b  and 85 read in the light of the other provisions of the Act was that if in a suit filed against the defendant on the footing that he is a trespasser he raises the plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to deal with the plea,

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 85(1) Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948

anchor.surface_text: Section 85A reads 85A  1 . If any suit instituted in any Civil Court involves any issues which are required to be settled, decided or dealt with by any authority competent to settle, decide or deal with such issues under this Act  hereinafter referred to as the competent authority  the Civil, Court shall stay the suit and refer such issues to such competent authority for determination. On receipt of such reference from the Civil Court, the competent authority shall deal with and decide such issues in accordance with the provisions of this Act and shall communicate its decision to the Civil Court and such Court shall thereupon dispose of the suit in accordance with the procedure applicable thereto. Explanation.-For the purpose of this section a Civil Court shall include a Mamlatdars Court constituted under the Mamlatdars Courts Act, 1906.

concepts.interpretation: Civil Court must stay suit and refer tenancy issues to competent authority (Mamlatdar); codifies pre-existing practice; combined with other sections gives exclusive jurisdiction to Mamlatdar over tenancy determination even in civil suits.

issues.text: Whether, in a suit for possession of agricultural lands on redemption of a mortgage where the defendant pleads that he is a protected tenant, the Civil Court has jurisdiction to decide the issue or must refer it to the Mamlatdar

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Patwardhan contended that the jurisdiction of a Civil Court depends upon the allegations made in the plaint, the Civil Court has full jurisdiction to try a suit for recovery of possession of agricultural lands on redemption of a mortgage and the Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to try such a suit, the plea in the written statement that the defendants were protected tenants did

issues.text: Whether the combined effect of sections 29, 70(b), 85 and 85A of the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948 requires a Civil Court to stay the suit and refer tenancy status issues to the Mamlatdar even in suits against alleged mortgagees or trespassers

anchor.surface_text: Section 85 1 provides that no Civil Court shall have jurisdiction to settle, decide or deal with any question which is by the Act required to be settled, decided or dealt with by the Mamlatdar. Section 85A reads 85A 1 . If any suit instituted in any Civil Court involves any issues which are required to be settled, decided or dealt with by any authority competent to settle, decide or deal with such issues under this Act hereinafter referred to as the competent authority the Civil, Court shall stay the suit and refer such issues to such competent authority for determination.

issues.text: Whether, prior to the introduction of section 85A by Bombay Act XIII of 1956, the Civil Court lacked jurisdiction over tenancy pleas raised in suits properly cognizable by it and had to refer such issues to the Mamlatdar under sections 70(b) and 85
Whether the High Court in second appeal had jurisdiction to set aside the first appellate Court's finding that nothing was due under the mortgage transaction

arguments.claim: The jurisdiction of a Civil Court depends upon the allegations made in the plaint, the Civil Court has full jurisdiction to try a suit for recovery of possession of agricultural lands on redemption of a mortgage, the Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to try such a suit, the plea that the defendants were protected tenants did not oust the jurisdiction of the Civil Court, and the Civil Court should have tried and decided the incidental issue whether the defendants were mortgagees or protected tenants instead of referring the issue to the Mamlatdar

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Patwardhan contended that the jurisdiction of a Civil Court depends upon the allegations made in the plaint, the Civil Court has full jurisdiction to try a suit for recovery of possession of agricultural lands on redemption of a mortgage and the Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to try such a suit,

arguments.court_reasoning: Even where Civil Court has jurisdiction over suit against mortgagee or trespasser, if tenancy plea raised creating issue under the Act, Civil Court must refer to Mamlatdar under combined effect of ss.29,70(b),85 (and later 85A), as held in Dhondi Tukaram and approved by legislature

arguments.claim: The High Court rightly referred the issue for the decision of the Mamlatdar

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, Mr. Gopalakrishnan disputed these contentions, and contended that the High Court rightly referred the issue for the decision of the Mamlatdar.

arguments.court_reasoning: Courts below were bound to refer the issue to Mamlatdar under pre-s.85A law as interpreted in Dhondi

arguments.claim: The combined effect of ss. 29, 70, 85 and 85A of the Act is that the Mamlatdar has exclusive jurisdiction over landlord possession applications against tenants, Civil Courts have no such jurisdiction, but Civil Courts have jurisdiction over suits against trespassers or mortgagees, though must refer tenancy status issues to Mamlatdar, stay suit, and decide based on Mamlatdar's decision

Independently of s.85A and before its enactment, the effect of ss.70(b) and 85 read with other provisions required Civil Court, in suit against alleged trespasser where tenancy plea raised, to lack jurisdiction over the plea and refer issue to Mamlatdar rather than dismiss outright

Dhondi Tukaram correctly interpreted pre-s.85A law by holding Mamlatdar has exclusive jurisdiction over tenancy issues even arising in Civil Court suits cognizable by it, as approved by Bombay Legislature which introduced s.85A to implement that view and provide machinery for reference

Prior to Dhondi, it was debatable whether 'for the purposes of this Act' in s.70 limited Mamlatdar's jurisdiction to proceedings under specific Act provisions or extended to issues in Civil Court suits (ouster via s.85), but Dhondi settled for extension and legislature approved

Mudugere Rangaiah v. M. Rangaiah holding Civil Court jurisdiction over tenancy dispute between rival tenants under Mysore Tenancy Act ss.32,46 (analogous to Bombay ss.70,85) is not opined upon, as question of Mysore Act interpretation does not arise and schemes differ

In the second appeal by plaintiff, the High Court had no jurisdiction to set aside the first appellate Court's finding in appellant's favour that nothing is due by the plaintiff to the defendants under Exhibit 43
arguments.court_reasoning: No substance, as first appellate Court recorded inconsistent findings

arguments.claim: Civil Court had no jurisdiction to determine whether defendant No. 1 was a mortgagee in possession or a tenant; nothing due under Ex.43 confirmed; remand to trial court to await tenancy proceedings outcome

anchor.surface_text: On July 5, 1955, the first appellate Court held that the Civil Court had no jurisdiction to determine whether defendant No. 1 was a mortgagee in possession or a tenant, and passed the following decree The appeal is partly allowed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Correct on no jurisdiction to decide tenancy issue and need to refer

arguments.claim: Lower appellate Court, having concluded no jurisdiction to interpret document Ex.43 (mortgage or lease), should not have taken accounts treating as mortgage; set aside that finding; confirm Civil Court no jurisdiction to interpret doc; refer issue to Mamlatdar whether defendant lessee/tenant under Ex.43

anchor.surface_text: On December 7, 1959, the High Court dismissed the second appeal. The High Court held The lower Appellate Court having come to the conclusion that it has got no jurisdiction to interpret this document, should not have taken the accounts, treating the document as a mortgage.

arguments.court_reasoning: Courts below bound to refer tenancy issue to Mamlatdar

arguments.claim: Deed Ex.43 is composite document comprising mortgage and lease; on mortgage accounts, plaintiff owed nothing on suit date so mortgage fully redeemed; plaintiff at liberty to seek possession remedy in Revenue Courts

anchor.surface_text: On March 4, 1953, the trial Court passed the following decree 10. A The deed Exhibit 43 is a composite document comprising of a mortgage and a lease. On taking accounts of the mortgage debt, it is found that plaintiff owed nothing to the defendants on the date of suit.

holdings.text: With regard to suits and proceedings by a landowner for possession of agricultural lands, the combined effect of ss. 29, 70, 85 and 85A of the Act is as follows: The Mamlatdar has exclusive jurisdiction to entertain an application by a landlord for possession of agricultural lands against a tenant, and the Civil Court has no jurisdiction to entertain and try a suit by a landlord against a tenant for possession of agricultural lands. The Mamlatdar has no jurisdiction to try a suit by a landowner for recovery of possession of agricultural lands from a trespasser or from a mortgagee on redemption of a mortgage, and the Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain such a suit but if the defendant to the suit pleads that he is a tenant or a protected tenant or a permanent tenant and an issue arises whether he is such a tenant, the Court must refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for determination, and must stay the suit pending such determination, and after the Mamlatdar has decided the issue, the Court may dispose of the suit in the light of the decision of the Mamlatdar.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to suits and proceedings by a landowner for pos- session of agricultural lands, the companybined effect of ss. 29, 70, 85 and 85A of the Act is as follows The Mamlatdar has exclusive jurisdiction to entertain an application by a landlord for possession of agricultural lands against a tenant, and the Civil Court has number jurisdiction to entertain and try a suit by a landlord against a tenant for possession of agricultural lands. The Mamlatdar has numberjurisdiction to try a suit by a landowner for recovery of possession of agricultural lands from a trespasser or from a mortgagee on redemption of a mortgage, and the Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain such a suit but if the defendant to the suit pleads that he is a tenant or a protected tenant or a permanent tenant and an issue arises whether he is such a tenant, the Court must refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for determination, and must stay the suit pending such determination, and after the Mamlatdar has decided the issue, the Court may dispose of the suit in the light of the decision of the Mamlatdar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious reading of ss.29, 70(b), 85, 85A with other provisions mandates Civil Court reference of tenancy issues to Mamlatdar even in suits otherwise cognizable by it against mortgagees or trespassers.

holdings.text: Dhondi Tukaram's case correctly interpreted the law as it stood before the enactment of s. 85A by holding that the Mamlatdar had exclusive jurisdiction to decide tenancy issues even though they arose for decision in a suit properly cognizable by a Civil Court.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent in Dhondi Tukaram settled debatable interpretation of 'for the purposes of this Act' in s.70 extending Mamlatdar jurisdiction to issues in Civil suits; affirmed by legislative approval via s.85A.

holdings.text: It follows that independently of s. 85A and under the law as it stood before s. 85A came into force, the Courts below were bound to refer to the Mamlatdar the decision of the issue whether the defendant is a tenant.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of affirmed pre-s.85A law (via Dhondi) to facts: Civil Court lacked jurisdiction over tenancy plea in mortgage redemption suit and had to refer to Mamlatdar.

holdings.text: There is no substance in this contention [that the High Court had no jurisdiction to set aside the finding of the first appellate Court that nothing is due by the plaintiff to the defendants under the transaction, Exhibit 43]. The first appellate Court recorded inconsistent findings.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's second appeal jurisdiction includes reviewing inconsistent findings of lower appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: Dhondi Tukarain v. Hari Dadu 1

precedents.cited_proposition: the effect of ss. 70 b and 85 read in the light of the other provisions of the Act was that if in a suit filed against the defendant on the footing that he is a trespasser he raises the plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant the Civil Court had numberjurisdiction to deal with the plea, and the proper procedure was to refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for his decision and number to ,,dismiss the suit straightaway
precedents.cited_holding: Therefore, we hold that in a suit filed against the defendant on the footing that he is a trespasser if he raises the plea that he is a tenant or a protected tenant, the Civil Court would have numberjurisdiction to deal with that plea. [...] the proper procedure to adopt in such cases would be to direct the party who raises such a plea to obtain a decision from the Mamlatdar within a reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1953 Dom. 969. s. 85A, it was a debatable point whether the expression for the, purposes of this Act meant that the Mamlatdar had jurisdiction to decide those issues only in some proceeding before him under some specific provision of the Act, or whether he had jurisdiction to decide those issues even though they arose for decision in a suit properly companysable by a Civil Court, so that the jurisdiction of the Civil Court to try those issues in the suit was taken away by s. 85 read with s. 70, Dhondi Tukarams case 1  settled the point

precedents.cited_proposition: the Mamlatdar had exclusive jurisdiction to decide those issues even though they arose for decision in a suit properly cognisable by a Civil Court

anchor.surface_text: Mudugere Rangaiah v. M. Rangaiah 2 , the plaintiff sued for a declaration that he is the kadim tenant in the suit land and prayed for a permanent injunction restraining the defendant from interfering with his possession.

precedents.cited_proposition: the jurisdiction of the Amildar is limited to cases arising by or under the Mysore Tenancy Act [...] the Civil Court had, therefore, the jurisdiction to decide all the points in dispute in the suit including the question of tenancy

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1959 Mysore 420. I.L.R. 1953 Bom. 969. Bombay Act. The Mysore High Court considered Dhondi Tukarams case 1 , and also numbered some of the points of distinction ,between the two Acts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sections 32 and 46 of the Mysore Act are similar to ss. 70 and 85 of the Bombay Act, but there are many points of distinction between the scheme and legislative history of the Mysore Act and those of the Bombay Act

anchor.surface_text: I.L.R. 1953 Bom. 969. Bombay Act. The Mysore High Court considered Dhondi Tukarams case 1 , and also numbered some of the points of distinction ,between the two Acts. In the instant case, the question of interpretation of ss. 32, 46 and other provisions of the Mysore Act does number arise, and we express numberopinion on it.

edges.explanation: h1 holding on combined effect of ss.29, 70, 85, 85A giving Mamlatdar exclusive jurisdiction directly addresses i2 on whether civil court must stay suit and refer tenancy status.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to suits and proceedings by a landowner for pos- session of agricultural lands, the companybined effect of ss. 29, 70, 85 and 85A of the Act is as follows The Mamlatdar has exclusive jurisdiction to entertain an application by a landlord for possession of agricultural lands against a tenant, and the Civil Court has number jurisdiction to entertain and try a suit by a landlord against a tenant for possession of agricultural lands. The Mamlatdar has numberjurisdiction to try a suit by a landowner for recovery of possession of agricultural lands from a trespasser or from a mortgagee on redemption of a mortgage, and the Civil Court has jurisdiction to entertain such a suit but if the defendant to the suit pleads that he is a tenant or a protected tenant or a permanent tenant and an issue arises whether he is such a tenant, the Court must refer the issue to the Mamlatdar for determination, and must stay the suit pending such determination, and after the Mamlatdar has decided the issue, the Court may dispose of the suit in the light of the decision of the Mamlatdar.

Consequently, the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts. Subsequent petitions by the plaintiff for review of this decree and for leave to file a Letters Patent Appeal were dismissed on April 14, 1960.
